There is a great wind that blows the clouds in all four directions and disperses them into the mountains.
Third, when there are thunder and lightning in the clouds, the diviners also predict rain.
At that time, the asuras grasp the floating clouds and place them in the great ocean.
Fourth, when there are thunder and lightning in the clouds, the diviners also predict rain.
But the rain-makers are unrestrained and licentious, and it still does not rain.
Fifth, when there are thunder and lightning in the clouds, the diviners also predict rain.
But the sentient beings in the world are unrestrained and indulgent, defiling the practice of purity.
They are stingy, greedy, and jealous, and their views are upside down.
Therefore, the heavens do not send rain.
These five things are not definite signs. From the second fascicle of the Chang ahan jing, the same as the Loutan jing.
